CHAPTER LXXI. now COPPER 1s BLACKENED.

CAUSE leaves of the above-mentioned copper, which is called red, to be thinned sor you, of the length you wish. When you have cut and adapted these to your work, portray upon them small flowers, or animals, or other thing which you wish, and sculp it with a fine sculping iron. Then take oil which is made from linseed, and anoint it all over thinly with the finger, and smooth it with a goose feather, and holding it with the forceps, place it upon the glowing embers; and

when it is a little warmed and the oil has become liquid, you ,

will smooth it anew with the pen, and you again place it upon the embers‚ and do thus until it is dried. But if you see that it is smooth every where, place it over some very hot coals, and let it lie until it be dried. And if it be black enough, it is well; but if not, you anoint a very little oil with the feather over the hot copper, and being made smooth, again place it upon the lighted coals, acting as before. When they have be- come cold, not in water, but alone, serape small flowers care- fully with very sharp scraping instmments‚ so that the grounds may appear black.
